full_title_en: Withdrawal Assessment Tool (WAT-1) for Pediatric Withdrawal
medium_description_en: Estimates severity of opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal in children.

seo.meta_description_en: The Withdrawal Assessment Tool (WAT-1) screens pediatric patients for opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal symptoms.
seo.keywords_en: WAT-1, withdrawal assessment tool, pediatrics, opioid, benzodiazepine

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Pediatric patients (age 2 weeks to 18 years in the original study) at risk for opioid withdrawal (i.e., on sedation for ≥5 days). 

  • Note that the population in this study was limited to those intubated for respiratory conditions, which, while common, may limit applicability to children intubated and sedated for other reasons (e.g. status epilepticus or head trauma).
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Children on round-the-clock sedation for ≥5 days (e.g. when intubated and sedated in the PICU) are at higher risk for withdrawal than children sedated for ≤4 days. Additionally, administration of sedatives via continuous or intermittent dosing does not alter the likelihood of withdrawal.

  • May be used to trend improvement or worsening in withdrawal symptoms over time.

  • WAT-1 scores ≥3 were 87.2% sensitive and 88% specific for predicting severe withdrawal symptoms, and correlated with longer duration of intubation and opioid sedation, longer time needed to wean from all sedatives, and greater length of stay (both PICU stay and overall hospitalization).

  • Withdrawal symptoms in neonates and infants may be subtler than in older children, and may include jitteriness, irritability, or inconsolability.

  • Patients being weaned from continuous sedation using agents such as morphine, methadone, or lorazepam should be monitored closely for respiratory depression and oversedation.
how_to_use.why_use_en: Up to 94% of PICUs experience issues with iatrogenic sedative withdrawal symptoms in their patients, which can prolong length of stay.

next_steps.advice_en:
• The original study authors recommend scoring from the first day of weaning in patients who have received opioids and/or benzodiazepines for ≥5 days (by infusion or periodic dosing), and to continue twice daily scoring until 72 hours after the last dose.

  • They also recommend completing along with the State Behavioral Scale (SBS) (see Evidence for details) at least once per 12 hour shift (e.g. at 8:00 and 20:00 ±2 hours). The progressive stimulus used in the SBS assessment provides a standard stimulus for observing signs of withdrawal.

  • Scores ≥3 suggest severe withdrawal symptoms. Children on continuous sedation for ≥5 days are more likely to have WAT-1 scores ≥3.

  • Up-trending scores suggest worsening withdrawal and may require addition of withdrawal-preventive medications (e.g. methadone or lorazepam), additional one-time doses, or adjustments in dose or dosing schedule.
next_steps.critical_actions_en:
• Consider addition of withdrawal-preventing medications in children on IV sedation for ≥5 days.

  • Frequently reassess children who are weaning off sedation medications for respiratory depression and oversedation. Oversedation can occur even in patients who have had severe withdrawal symptoms, and may require rescue medications like naloxone.

about.evidence_based_medicine_en:
Franck et al (2008) developed the WAT-1 using data from a population of 83 mechanically ventilated children in acute respiratory failure sedated with either continuous drips or round-the-clock dosing of opiates and/or benzodiazepines. They found good interrater reliability for the WAT-1, and were able to achieve similar sensitivity and specificity as other withdrawal scores like the Finnegan Neonatal Abstinence Score).

Despite there being no standardized sedation weaning protocol used at either of the two study institutions, the derivation study was overall quite robust. The WAT-1 was consistent and strongly correlated with duration and dosage of sedation medications.

Franck et al (2012) validated their findings in 308 children, showing that WAT-1 scores ≥3 correlated with higher total opioid and benzodiazepine doses, longer pre-wean duration of sedation, and need for a longer weaning period as compared to children with WAT-1 scores <3.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Franck LS, Harris SK, Soetenga DJ, Amling JK, Curley MA. The Withdrawal Assessment Tool-1 (WAT-1): an assessment instrument for monitoring opioid and benzodiazepine withdrawal symptoms in pediatric patients. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2008;9(6):573-80.

Other References.text: Curley MA, Harris SK, Fraser KA, Johnson RA, Arnold JH. State Behavioral Scale: a sedation assessment instrument for infants and young children supported on mechanical ventilation. Pediatr Crit Care Med. 2006;7(2):107-14.

Validation.text: Franck LS, Scoppettuolo LA, Wypij D, Curley MA. Validity and generalizability of the Withdrawal Assessment Tool-1 (WAT-1) for monitoring iatrogenic withdrawal syndrome in pediatric patients. Pain. 2012;153(1):142-8.

expert_name.description: Derek Tam, MD, MPH, is a pediatric resident at Maimonides Children's Hospital in Brooklyn, NY. Dr. Tam completed an undergraduate degree in cognitive science at Northwestern University in Chicago, IL, and received his MD and MPH from the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine. He will serve as chief resident for the pediatric residency program at Maimonides for the academic year 2019-2020 and plans to pursue a fellowship in pediatric emergency medicine. His academic interests include emergency medicine, pediatric resuscitation, antibiotic stewardship, and epidemiology.
expert_name.name: Derek Tam, MD, MPH

creator_info.about_en: Linda S. Franck, RN, PhD, FRCPCH, is a professor of family health care nursing at University of California, San Francisco (UCSF). She is also the co-principal investigator for the UCSF Preterm Birth Initiative. Dr. Franck’s primary research is focused on improving family-centered care.
